reviews.review_msg: This was the only truely cognitive science course at SFU.  The custom courseware was great.  Spent a good bit of time dealing with the philosophical issues.  Not recommended for typical CMPT students who dream of a cubical with 8 computers to program on

(CMPT 419/726, Fall 2015) Do not underestimate the prereqs; this is the hardest undergrad CMPT course at SFU. I recommend taking at least MATH 251 and 309, and STAT 285. Greg has a superhuman skill to explain machine learning in depth but also with clarity, a rare combination in post-secondary. He also responds to emails blazing fast.
A very good professor! He is good at this field and his teaching style is humorous and friendly. Grading is fair.
Really well organized course for any individual who want to get involved in the world of machine learning and its application

Machine Learning is a tough course. The heavy math prereq of an A in every UG math course is not just for show, so know what you're getting into beforehand. Greg takes a topic with tons of complexity and abstract high-dimensional concepts and explains them clearer than anyone else could without dumbing things down. You will learn amazing things.
Very Unfair

Amazing professor! This course is *not* for you unless you really want to learn. And if you do, you'll find it amazing. Mori covers tons of material, but in an extremely clear and understandable manner. He's really smart, and also really modest, so he's very approachable. Exam was very fair, and the assignments really reinforce the material.
He just tries to show he is smart by making the course unnecessarily difficult and heavy.  :-(
An average instructor

Spent two course worth of time on this ONE course on all the assignments and stuff but i indeed learned a lot. Very math focused but it is indeed a very structured course and Prof ke is very helpful. However, he is almost always late for his class and office hours.
one of the best profs I've had in sfu

His assignments are tough but you really learn the actually concepts of the course and can connect how things works. Overall very good experience with the prof. I will recommend you guys to take this course for machine learning.

The course is very math focused, it is HIGHLY recommended to take statistics, linear algebra and calc 3. The assignments are tough but he gives you a lot of time but the assignments seem original and relate to the course. He marks fairly and he wants you to succeed in this couse.

I think Ke's in person lectures are pretty good. He explains things well and if you didn't understand something the first time, the slides have all the information you need to figure things out. I really appreciate that Ke answers "dumb" questions with patience and without judgement and also answers difficult questions adequately.

Ke li is actually a wonderful professor. Machince learning is hard to teach well imo but i think hes doing a good job, courses very well structured. Those who rated him bad must be the slackers/dropouts. But yes, cmpt419 is extremely hard if your math skill is not up to par. I would not recommend it cuz this is like a 4 hundred level math course

I think it's unfair to rate the prof 1.0/5.0 because you can see he does put a lot of work into his lecture slides. He tried to explain at his best ability. Machine learning related courses are just by design very difficult. So I think those quizzes and assignments he put out really helps with the understanding.

There is mandatory participation and we had to keep our cameras on even if we were living with family in a small house. There is quizzes every week and two assignments and one final, sometimes subjects related to the quedtions in assignments were being covered after due date. Professor tried to explain everything but he is not good at it.

Ke is a pretty good especially since he's just starting as a prof. Can tell he cares about the students. Takes time to read emails and writes detailed responses. Recaps the previous class which helps a lot. Always makes himself available for help. Encourages and lets us ask questions at any point in lectures. Can tell he puts in the effort ��

Remote grad/undergrad course graded on attendance for some reason. VERY difficult to follow. Much of the lecture is just "right uhh, you know, uhh, this thing equals that thing, uhh, you know". Often changes subject mid sentence. Nice guy though, happy to answer questions (if you can understand his answer). He just isn't great at teaching.
Always start lecture few minutes late and never end class on time. Mandatory attendance and cam required. Most online free ML course would teach better than this prof.

She really cares and is very passionate about the course topics. Some people are mad about the final curve but that is just because everyone scored very high on assignments and there needed to be some grade distribution. Not everyone can get an A

I took 419, 310 and 376w with Angelica and she was great for all 3. This class in particular was the most interesting and we were given a lot of space for creativity with the group project. She is passionate about teaching and that translates really well to her lectures. Definitely recommend taking any course she is teaching.
Pretty good Prof, Cares and is thoughtful

Absolutely absurd grading criteria. Like 89+ will be an A-. Bruh. Prof herself is super overrated imo. She wasn't even able to answer challenging questions during the class. The material provided was easy and useless considering this is a 400 lvl course. Overall not too bad but she is just mediocre. Other 419 profs like Nick Vincent is far better.

Professor Lim is one of my favourite professors I've encountered at SFU. Assignments were a lot of work but taught you a lot. Exams were difficult but fair. Final project was great. She really cares about her students and is very approachable outside of class if you need any help. You can tell she's passionate about her work. 10/10 highly recommend

CMPT419 is really hard. I've done ML, now I'm in Robotic Autonomy. Mo knows what he is doing and doesn't dumb down the material. I can see classes like this making me get paid more in the future, thats why I took it, while a lot of people dropped. The class is hard! high risk, high reward. My only issue is that questions on piazza got ignored

Average prof, its his second semester teaching. He knows the slide content, but not deeper. He doesn't know practical details for neural networks, his background is in reinforcement learning (for which he'll be an expert). the 3 TAs are only available on thursdays, im on another campus that day. the prof should do somthing about this
